text: Garish purple light spills out of side-street porno house illuminating a silhouette, and little else, of a MAN lean against an alley wall. He is waiting. Another silhouetted FIGURE appears and approaches the fir They size each other up as best they can.
MacLeod.
The second nods. The first without hesitation raises a sword, the intended thrust interrupted by his own death as the second with a of metal severs the agressor's head.

A 15th century Scottish home. A haggard WOMAN, her small CHILD clinging to a tattered a stands hunched over a glowing hearth.  Her veined hands d a wooden spoon around and around through a soot-covered p of grey soup. From an adjoining room CONOR MACLEOD, a young man dressed in his best traditional Celtic tartan, enters.
My, but are you the picture.
(surveying himself) It's a bit tight.
His FATHER enters with a pail of milk.
Ah, Conor, how you look a man.
Have you time for some- thing to eat?
No, Mother.  They'll be here shortly.
Conor's father looks him over with pride.
Your grandfather wore that in his service to the King, and I to fight for the Duke.
Must he go?
Aye.  It is his duty.  All of ours.
But Ian, he's still but a boy.
He's a MacLeod.
I'll be fine Mother.
Several HORSEMEN gallop up through the early morning fog the cottage door. Conor's father steps out to meet them.
A massive KNIGHT sits astride his horse, moorish dew clin ing to his helmet and breastplate.  A CLANSMAN hikes up t heather-carpeted slope to him.
They march.
Is the boy among them?
Aye.
The second kneels to examine the headless body of the fir With a CLACK a window, high on the alley wall, closes.

The DUKE is leading a brigade of CLANSMEN out onto the pl Mounted VASSALS ride back and forth inspecting the line. low fog makes it impossible to see beyond a few yards.  T is an erie, smothering silence.
Is a bad day for this.
The Duke has been compro- mised.  He will have his due.
By day's end he will have our heads.
We ride against the Suther- lands.  That is all that matters.
This makes no sense to me.
And a friend are marching through the moist heather.
The fog is bad.  We cannot even see the sides of our own ranks.
Conor's nervousness is showing.
Is this your first?
Aye.
SHOUTING is heard on the plain.
It's begun.
The Knight, above the fog, hears the battle commence belo He spurs his horse and starts down into the mist.

The two opposing clans are now one confused mass of tarta and clashing swords.  The air is charged with SHOUTS of e citement, agony, and the SHRILL of bag pipes. The fog has made each man's battle his own, each isolated his opponent.
Rides calmly through the fracas.  He strikes and kills th that assault him, but appears disinterested in battle. He is looking.

Is standing above the twitching body of his friend. Alone and confused, Conor has become seperated from the c He stumbles through the fog, seeking help. Suddenly he is alone with the Knight. The face of iron locks its gaze onto the boy.  His fear t to panic, Conor turns and flees. The Knight, his resolve steeled in a raised sword, kicks horse into persuit. Conor is easily overtaken and on his first pass the Knigh brings his blade down hard into Conor's shoulder, slicing open most of the boy's back and knocking him face-first i the heather. As Conor watches his own blood spew forth, he rolls over time to see the Knight dismount and start for him.
Leans down next to Conor, his metal face nearly against t boy's.  His voice slithers out of the iron in almost a wh
There can be but one.

Charges out of the fog and attacks the Knight, who cuts h nearly in half.  ANOTHER wanders in and meets the same fa The battle is shifting to where they are. Not finished yet with Conor, the Knight is finding himsel forced into retreat from an ever increasing number of ass ants.
Sees his men being hacked apart trying to stop the now-mo Knight.
Leave him!

The clansmen obey. With the slap of an armored gauntlet against his steed, t Knight disappears into the fog. The Vassal surveys the carnage before him.  His eyes fall moment on the moaning, gurgling Conor. The Vassal turns and leaves the boy for dead.
A patrol car pauses at the mouth of the alley. The figure considers his situation, then quickly shoves h sword into a near-by drain.  He straightens up and waits.
Steps out of his unit and cautiously walks forward.  His switches on the patrol car's side lamps, bathing the alle in a harsh glare.

For the first time we can see his face.  RICHARD TAUPIN, in a well-cut business suit, looks exactly like Conor. The police officer, upon seeing the body, grabs instincti for his pistol.  He yells to his partner now coming into alley.
Kevin!  Get is a backup.
I was merely walking by when-
Don't move.
The officer has his pistol out and leveled. His partner runs up, shotgun in hand.
They're on their way.
His voice cuts short as the blood flows against his shoe.
Christ.
Conor lies moaning on a cot.  Makeshift bandages wrap his body, stained and pasted by thick, dried blood. The family surrounds their dying son. A PRIEST is delivering the last rites.
...Libera Domine Animan servi tui sicut libertasi David de manu regis Saul...
His sobbing mother holds a compress to Conor's forehead.
...In mamus tuas domine commendo spiritum meum...
A Vassal rides up to the hutch, dismounts, and approaches CLANSMAN standing in the open doorway.
Has the boy died?
He is having the last rites now.  It should be over by morning.
Never seen anybody cut as bad live so long.  He should have died on the field.
Tonight or tomorrow, it's all the same.
The Vassal peers inside at the priest administering the sacraments.
...Auditorium nostrum in nomine domini...
This has been a dark day.
...Requiescant in pace...
There is a bustle of activity.  Setting up barricades, un formed OFFICERS are trying to keep NEW CREWS and curious ONLOOKERS at a distance.
Lean, fortyish, and comfortable with the gore in front of is inspecting the corpse with a MEDICAL EXAMINER.
(studying body) Real clean.  No sawing action at all.  Whatever it was did it in one swipe. (looks up at Moran) Like the other one.
Moran gestures to a sword, wrapped in plastic, lying near
What about that?
Hasn't any blood on it.
(looking around) About the only thing that doesn't.
I'll give it a closer look when I get back.
Pretty but not beautiful, thirtyish, she exudes a sort of insolent intelligence. An OFFICER sees her duck under a police barricade.
Come on Brenna, you know better than that.
I'm invited.
She walks to where the medical examiner is organizing his equipment.
(greeting) Mr. Levine...
The examiner turns and smiles.
Hope this isn't past your bedtime.
Brenna looks to the now-sheeted corpse, blood flowing fro where the head should be.
Doesn't have a head, does he?
This one came unassembled.
Lt. Moran is standing near.
(no warmth) Just show her what she came for, Tom.
(stands, taps Brenna's arm) Come on, this is more your line of work.
Brenna and the examiner walk the few yards from the corps to the sword.
How's your uncle?  I hardly ever see him anymore.
Fine.
The examiner stops and gestures to the weapon clothed in forensic plastic.
There you go.
Brenna's expression changes to interest as she kneels dow beside it.
Didn't look like it came from "Toys-Are-Us", that's why I called you.
(looks up in Moran's direction) Didn't think it was my buddy over there.
Figured you knew more about swords than I did.
Claymore.
Huh?
Scottish claymore.  Take a French epee, add twenty pounds of ballast so it means business, and you've got a claymore.
You're the expert.
(runs hand along hilt, slightly confused) It's in good condition.
Is being put in the rear of a patrol car.  Brenna studies face in the half-gloom.  There's something different abou A steadiness.

Richard Taupin is seated at a graffitti scrawled table in room otherwise bare of furnishings.  He seems unphased by surroundings. The door opens and Moran enters with bag and notebook.  H picks up Taupin's wallet on the table top and checks the driver's license.
This your present address?
Yes.
Mr.- (looks at license) Taupin, what were you doing in that alley?
I was walking by when I heard a shout.  Your men came right after.
Did you know the victim?
No.
His name was Iman Fasil if that jogs your memory.
It doesn't.
He was carrying a Syrian passport and had been in the country less than a week.
Taupin's face is stoic and controlled.
Two days ago a Bulgarian national was murdered the same way.  He'd also been in the country less than a week. (beat) What is your citizenship?
American.
Moran paces to a corner of the room.
Do you make a habit of hanging out in that neigh- borhood at night?
What are you getting at?
Let's just say that in my years with this department I've seen more than one well dressed business man look for a hand job on 14th Street.
Moran places both hands on the table and leans across it.
What were _you_ looking for?
That's none of your business.
You're wrong.
Moran reaches into a bag on the table and removes a large broad sword; old, but in mint condition.
Do you know what this is?
I presume it's a sword.
A claymore to be exact.  You wouldn't know anything about it would you?
Your murder weapon?
It was covered with Mr. Fasil's fingerprints, but none of his blood.
A mystery.
For the moment.
Moran turns the sword over in his hand then sets it down. He rises and opens the door.
All right Mr. Taupin, we'll be in touch.
Taupin passes through the doorway without comment.
Taupin out into the crisp night air.  His eyes search out darkness.
A medieval sun beats down on an OLD TRAVELER making his w the MacLeod home.  Conor's mother, scrubbing clothes in a bucket, smiles in recognition.
Ah Steven, it is good to see you.
I only just heard of Conor.  I came up from Catroch as soon as I could.
You're a kind man to be sure.
I thought it only proper to pay me last respects to the family.
Steven, Conor didn't die.
But I had heard his wounds were mortal.
They were Steven, they were.  It's been a miracle it has.  He lasted right through and healed.  No one in the village has ever seen anything like it.  Ever.
Perched on a heather-carpeted rise above the village a yo woman, MARA, sits contemplating the intricaces of a daffo Balancing on a shepard's staff, Conor limps over and puts his lips to her ear.
You're pretty today.
Mara is silent.  Distant.
I'm your future husband, remember?
I have no future husband.
I don't understand.  Not a week ago your father gave us his blessing.
This is difficult for her.  Tears well in her eyes.
My future husband died in battle against the Sutherlands.
What are you saying?  I'm standing here as real as you.
You cannot be real, Conor.  You had the last rites.  No man has been cut half as bad and lived.
But I did live.
Live?  In less than a week you're prancing about the country like a squirrel.
So why the crazy talk?  It's a miracle it is.  Saint Andrew has smiled on me.  On us.
Some think not.
Who?
There's rumor in the village. Some call it magic.
That's mad.  Surely you don't take their word?
I don't know, Conor.  It's not natural.  Maybe something has touched you.
You're sounding like that mad woman, Widow Baggins.
Me father has taken back my hand.
He puts a hand to her cheek.
Ah, Lassie...
She steps back.
Please not be touching me, Conor.
I'll not take that kind of talk from you.  From those others below, maybe.  But not from you.
Leave me alone, Conor.  Please.
You're not talking sense, Mara!
Anger tumbles into exasperation.
I'm sorry.
He steps for her.  She moves away.  Conor's face hardens resentment.
If you send me away now, Mara, I'll not come looking for you.
(crying) Do what you must.
Resigned, Conor turns and limps away.
Classy antiques.  Unusual.  Clocks, tables, chests.  Smal personal. Richard Taupin enters and sheds his overcoat.
Mrs. Thompson agreed to settle for fifteen, Melvin's wants to make a pick-up at three o'clock, the coffee machine's broken, and there's a Miss Cartwright from the Smithsonian in your office.
Taupin is hardly in the mood.
Brenna Cartwright stands in Taupin's cluttered surroundin admiring a bagpipe set neatly on a shelf.
Do you play?
Yes.
Very traditional.
Taupin sits down and begins sorting through a stack of pa on his desk.
(impatient) Miss Cartwright, what is it I can do for you?
I'd like to ask you about the claymore.
It's not mine.
It's quite rare you know, some- thing so common in its time so well looked after all these years.
Miss Cartwright, unless you have come here to sell the sword, there's very little I can help you with.  Now if you will excuse me, I have a great deal of work to do.
Brenna has taken a carving from the shelf.
Byzantine?
Basil the II.
Charming guy, Basil.  Once after beating an army of Serbians he blinded all but-
-All but one out of a hundred, I know.  All left to be led like donkeys back home.  Now if you will please-
Brenna suddenly tosses the carving at him.  Taupin snatch out of the air with lightning precision.
Good reflexes.
Good day, Miss Cartwright.

A lonely, ancient room full of equal parts dust and oaken study tables. The department SUPERVISOR sits at his desk surrounded by handful of his staff RESEARCHERS - Brenna included.  A fa stern portrait of some forgotten curator presides over pr up feet, cold coffee, and half eaten sack lunches.
I don't believe him.
Why?
He's too cool.  Too sharp.  I think he's got something to do with it.
Oh, has your penetrating research on 9th Century Lithuanian dildos suddenly made you an expert on the criminal mentality?
Screw off, Larry.
The men, LAUGH.  They delight in baiting her. Researcher #2 opens a Budweiser and pours the beer into a mug he's borrowed from the collection.
The cops bought it.  They let him go.
What could they hold him for?  I think they're just waiting for something concrete before they haul him in for real.  We should look into it.  He had to have gotten that sword from somewhere.
Hang on a sec, you did your little favor for the boys downtown, I'm sure your uncle and the rest are perfectly capable of taking it from here.
I've seen nobleman swords that weren't as well preserved.  It's just a hunk of peasant iron.  Why would he be carrying it around in an alley?
Here we go.  Everytime there's a murder in town we have to put up with junior D.A.
Must be genetic.
Someone should check him out. Maybe a collection somewhere got knocked over.  He has one, he might have two.
You see that desk?  _Your_ desk?  You see the crap piled up on it?
Give it a rest Ned, huh?
Might be interesting to see what his family connections are.  That's a hell of a piece to be just chuck- ing around in an alley.
(sighs) I swear to God Brenna, between you and Thompson's novels I'm going to get a bloody ulcer.
Researcher #2 lifts the mug of beer to his mouth.

An empty mug is set on the counter of a medieval drinking establishment. CLANSMEN, their faces and clothes smudged with a day's wo the fields, relax and enjoy the company of their fellow V No longer requiring the use of a cane, Conor enters.
(to owner) Evening, Douglas.
Conor.
The tavern goes silent.  Wary.  The attention is on Conor
Ale suits me.
The owner unenthusiastically fills Conor a mug.  Conor ta it and walks to where four other VILLAGERS sit.
We rather you not be sitting with us, Conor.
Conor looks to the next table.
We be drinking alone as well.
The entire tavern spells the same sentiments.
What's wrong with you all?
Silence. Angered, Conor approaches the second man.  As he looms ab his chair the man in genuine fear pulls out a cross and t it forward.
Requiem acer'nam donaei-
What are you doing man?
-Et lux perpetua-
You'll not be bringing the church into this.
-Luceat ei-
The weird display frightens Conor.
Be quiet.
-Auditorium nostrum-
Stop.
-In nomine sanctus esperitu-
Stop!
Conor HURLES his mug against the wall. His nerves shattered, he rushes out.
Conor packs a satchel with his few clothes and belongings He walks to the doorway where his mother and father wait. His mother, tears on her cheek, hugs him tightly.
Please take care of yourself.
Aye.
Conor turns to his father.
I wish there was some other way.
They clasp hands.
Goodbye, Conor.
Goodbye.
Without looking back he passes through the doorway and do empty path, his figure quickly fading in the moorish fog.

The NOISY business-as-usual confusion at the Washington P processing center. Amongst the dinge of CLANGING phones and CLACKING typewri a uniformed OFFICER enters something into a computer term Brenna sits perched on a desk nearby.
This is against the rules.
So's playing choo-choo with two high school cheerleaders in the middle of-
-Okay okay.
You owe me.  Besides, I'm cute.
The computer returns a reply onto a printer.
(tears off sheet) Taupin, Richard Marshall.  Born March 16, 1945 in Church Hill, Maryland.  Received first driver permit 1967 in Philadelphia.
Church Hill, that's pretty close, isn't it?
Anything in Maryland is close.

Taupin steps out of a Metro station and walks the few blo to his brick townhouse.  Climbing the front stairs, he fi his keys out of a coat pocket.  About to insert the key h sensing something. Backing down the steps, Taupin slips around to the rear o building.

Like a spider Taupin pries open a window and slips silent inside. The home is dark and still. Taupin creeps down the hallway and peers into the entrywa There a MAN, dressed in a tuxedo jacket and nearly imperc in the dim light, is crouched at the front door. He is holding a sword. Taupin removes a knife from his pocket and JUMPS the intr The two STRUGGLE fiercely. Taupin pins the intruder against the carpet and shoves hi knife firmly against the man's throat.
Where is he?
Bulging eyes stare at him.
Where!
I don't know.
What name is he using?
Taupin presses the blade.  A trickle of blood rolls down throat.
Smith.  Carl Smith.
How many came?
The last four.
And the Bulgarian?
He got him. (hoarse chuckle) He always does.  Eventually.
He knows I'm here.  How?
None of this would be happening if you hadn't run...
The knife is pressed deeper.
_Answer_ me.
(gasping) We learned he'd found the immigration notaries in Liverpool and traced them to New York.  Then he figured out the birth records in Church Hill...
A city limit sign announcing the small community of Churc Hill is overtaken by Brenna's sedan.
Brenna looks through a telephone book.
Taupin...Taupin...
Nothing.  She closes the book and drums her fingers on th
An 1860s stone columned affair, far more impressive than low-lying town that surrounds it. Brenna enters.
Brenna sits sifting through a large cloth-bound book enti _Certificates of Birth: 1941-1948_.
(reading) Tarmin...Tatum...Taupin, Richard Marshall.  Born to William and Karen Taupin, no address.  Attend- ing physician, Dr. Willis Kidell.
Dr. Kidell stands at his bookcase leafing through a binde
1945, that strains the memory. (after a fashion) Here we are, Richard Taupin.
He carries the binder to the table where Brenna sits.
Would you like more tea?
No thank you, I'm fine.
Kidell sips his own and looks over the binder page.
He was unsual.
Why?

Well, this is a small town, and it was even smaller then.  Most all the babies I delivered were from local families.  Richard's parents were just passing through when his mother's time came.  I did it right here at the house.
Then you didn't know Richard later on.
No.
I've been trying to find somebody who knew him and any connections his family might have had with museums or historical societies.
Don't know about any of that. Suppose nobody does.
I don't follow you.
Poor little tyke didn't have a chance.  Hopelessly premature.  He died a few days after he was born.
The boy _died_?
Mother too.  Sad case it was.  The young lady just couldn't make it through labor.  Never even saw her son.
Dr. Kidell removes from the binder a tattered newspaper c
My brother worked for the town paper at the time.  He took this picture of the funeral.
Something in the clipping sparks Brenna's interest.
Have you spoken to anyone else about this?
There was this one fella.  Asked a lot of questions.  I was out of town but I heard he spent near a full day in the records office.
Would you remember his name?
(thinks) Carl Smith.
A police line-up. Seven MEN, all dressed in Santa Claus outfits with bare l are paraded for a small, old LADY.
Just tell us when you see the one.
Several rows back in the dark sits Brenna's UNCLE JOE, th district attorney, and another man, his ASSISTANT.
Forget it.
I'm just curious.
You're never "just curious". (to assistant) You've met my neice, Brenna.
Hi Brenna.
(to line-up) Number 5, lift your coat up more.
Aren't you getting a little old for this?  You flunked out of law school.
(rolls her eyes) Now there's a new topic.
Don't they have enough for you to do at the castle?
Brenna puts on her best little-girl angelic smile, a smil uncle can never refuse.
(sighs) Forgers do it all the time.  They take the birth certificate of some- one who died young and use it to get legit I.D.  Usually they carry it long enough to pass some bad checks then dump it.
Thanks.
Call your mother.  You never call her.
(to old lady) Well?
I don't know.  I'd have to see his thing.
A swath of moonlight shines in across a carafe-turned-vas a New England college diploma, and a police uniform hangi from the bedpost where Brenna lies with another man, DENN
I can't figure out why he's doing it. He's been Richard Taupin at least since 1967.  And the guys rich.  You should see the stuff he has in that shop.
Maybe he's hiding from something.
Some guy named Smith was asking about him in Church Hill.  I passed his name around with your buddies downtown but they drew a blank.  So he isn't a cop.  District anyway.
Dennis gets out of bed and begins putting on his uniform.
Probably just some exec ducking an ex-wife.
Dr. Kidell had a picture in his file of the funeral.  The father looked just like Richard.  Even had a mark on his cheek.
How old is Richard?
P.D. says 41, but he barely looks 30.
Find the father.  That should clear things up.
He buttons his shirt.  Something occurs to him.
Taupin, isn't that the guy Moran picked up the other night?
Yeah.
He'd want to know about all this.
Mr. Congeniality?  Let him find his own clues.  There's a journal article in this somewhere.
(shakes head) Uncle Joey's little girl.  Can't get the taste out of her mouth.
Dennis puts on his police cap.
Well, the cream of society awaits. (cocks hat to one side) If you're ever in the neighborhood...
Sure.
POLICE OFFICERS, their flashlights cutting the darkness, the mud shores of a Potomac tidal basin.  The glowing Jef Memorial can be seen in the distance.
Is supervising.  An OFFICER climbs up the embankment to h
They found it.
The officer leads him down to the river where a headless wearing a tuxedo jacket is being put into a plastic bag.
It was about fifty yards down- stream from the head.
Moran looks down at the body bag, its dark plastic reflec the rythmic rotation of squad car beacons.
Both were cut real clean.  Like the other ones...

A steeple-chase course lies shrouded in an Arlington fog. Across the damp grass a lone horse, heaving clouds of war breath, leaps gracefully over a hurdle.  Driving the stee hard through the course, Taupin pulls firm on the reins, bringing horse and rider to a shuddering stop where Detec Moran waits.
There's been another murder.
Taupin lifts his eyes to the suburban treeline.
My condolences.
Where were you Tuesday night?
Home.
A neighbor saw your car leave.
He's mistaken.
Taupin climbs down from his horse.  Moran moves close.
Look, I don't know what the hell you're up to, but I think I've got a pretty good idea.
Do you?
All I need is time.
I've got all the time in the world. (looks at watch) Except right now.  If you will excuse me, Lieutenant.
In no hurry, Taupin leads his horse away.

Brenna sits surrounded by books of old English law, color family banner plates, and a medieval caltrap sitting on h desk corner. Boring quickly, she shuts the book and sighs.  From anoth folder she pulls out a computer sheet.

The police sheet has Taupin's name and motor vehicle reco Below are listed four WILLIAM TAUPINS, their hometowns an driving records.  Richard Taupin's first driver permit wa 1967. Brenna looks down the list to a WILLIAM TAUPIN of Felton, Delaware, who stopped filling for driver permits in 1967, year Richard started.
Dropping a couple of quarters into a vending machine, Bre removes and opens up a map of the State of Delaware.

Brenna steps out of her car at a small town cemetary. Holding a slip of paper, she weaves her way through the s covered tombs of revolutionary heroes and their descendan On a small rise fresh dirt lies in careless piles around open grave. Richard Taupin stands at the mouth of the pit. A coffin has been brutally pulled from the dirt and lies and propped diagonally beside a marker that reads: "WILLI MICHAEL TAUPIN". The casket is empty.
Someone beat you.
Have you taken to touring small town cemetaries, Miss Cartwright?
Grave robbers?
Probably.
Who?
People like that rarely leave business cards.
Does Carl Smith?
A flash of interest, quickly suppressed.
I don't know what you're talking about.
I think you do.  Better yet, I don't think anything was stolen because nothing was there in the first place. And I think Mr. Smith, whoever he is, now knows that.
You have an active imagination.
I've been to Church Hill.
Miss Cartwright, you are involving yourself in matters that do not concern you.  I strongly suggest you return to Washington and stay out of small town cemetaries.
He starts for the gate.
I could find him.
Taupin stops.
I have friends.
I doubt that. (beat) Good day, Miss Cartwright.
He walks on. After only a few paces Taupin suddenly shudders to an abr stop.
What's wrong?
He holds up an open palm to silence her.
Your help may be unneccessary.
The air is still. Taupin's face is expressionless.  He listens intently.  S An unseen voice rides seemingly on the wind.
(o.s.) Good afternoon, "Mr. Taupin".

Taupin whirls around to see a large man standing with bro sword in hand.  We have never seen the knight out of his before, but this man certainly seems to fit the bill.  We Levis and leather jacket in contrast to Taupin's expensiv business suit, he speaks with icy evenness from a face of Taupin, naked without his own sword, is trapped against a marble wall.
Long time.
Not so long.
The Knight is closing in on him, sword gripped in both ha
You've been here from the start.
My quarry grows clever with age.  And the others, incompetent.
The Knight throws Brenna a glance.
Friend of yours?
Of sorts.
I do hope she enjoys a good show.
The Knight leans his whole body into a two-fisted swing, clanging out a chunk of marble as Taupin ducks. A second swipe also imbeds itself in stone.
So now it ends.
A thrust cuts only air.
Generation upon generation. Tens of thousands of miles.
Taupin leaps behind a tree.  The Knight cuts it nearly in
You're the last, MacLeod. Romirez, Lacroux, Neuvich, those fools that followed me, their heads all line my shelf.  All but yours.
Taupin drops to the ground in a shoulder roll to avoid a
Can you feel it, MacLeod? Can you _feel_ it!
Taupin grabs a tree branch and raps the Knight on the kne knocking him over. The Knight quickly rights himself and cuts the branch fro Taupin.
There can be but one.
He raises his blade. An elderly WATCHMAN, shotgun cradled in his arms, stands the clearing.
Hey!  What's going on here?
The Knight pauses a split second then with decision launc his sword spear-style firmly into the watchman's chest. Taupin pushes past him to Brenna.
Run!
Brenna is frozen in shock. Taupin shoves her roughly toward the gate.
Run!
MACLEOD!
The Knight retrieves his sword from the watchman's body a lumbers after them. Taupin and Brenna bolt from the cemetary and into the sur ing residential area.
Taupin leads an exhausted Brenna in a gallop down the sid walk. They have apparently lost the Knight.  Taupin pauses at a corner.  He sees a church across the street.

Brenna enters and collapses into a pew, her labored breat echoing off the high ceiling. Taupin walks the length of an aisle to see that they are Satisfied, he leans against a banister and considers his uation. Trying to recover her wind, Brenna has her eyes closed an head against the back of the pew.
Jesus Christ.
You'll be safe here.  He won't kill in a church.
Why not?
(distracted) Tradition.
What the hell is going on?
Taupin stares out the window, stained glass shining orang his face.  He looks at Brenna briefly, then passes throug Church's doorway without a word.

A glowing horseshoe HISSES wildly as it slips into a wood cooling bucket.  Pulling it out with iron tongs, Conor la it on a counter and pounds it even with a mallet. Sweaty and streaked with dirt, he tosses the mallet aside and walks out into the late afternoon sunshine.
Conor leans over a water barrel and dunks his head and ar cleaning off a day's worth of sweat and grime.
Stirring up dust with his travelling boots, this Spanish ented man stops at Conor's shop.  He wears a large broad strapped to his waist.
Afternoon.
Your name is Conor?
Aye.
(bows slightly) Juan Cid Romirez.  Chief surveyor and alchemist.
(notices accent) You're not from these parts.
I am from Spain.  And I would like a moment of your time.
Romirez is seated at a table.  His back to the Spaniard, Conor is preparing some food.
I haven't much to offer, Mr. Romirez from Spain, but you're welcome to what's here.
Please go to no trouble.
Romirez is looking at the faint, pale hint of a scar that runs from Conor's shoulder blade to his waist.
Your back, it would seem perhaps you were injured in battle?
Five years past me clan fought another over some- thing I cannot even re- member.
Your marks would suggest great injury.
I was nearly killed.
But you lived.
Conor looks up from his work in pained memory.
I did at that.
And but for a mark you are well as any man, no?
Aye.
I should imagine that your recovery must have alarmed your fellow villagers, perhaps giving them reason to invent an explanation.  And a solution.
Something isn't right. Conor turns and faces him.
I was driven out.
And now you live in a small village miles away from all you knew.
How can you know this?
(tone lightens) First food, no?  A good meal makes conversation so much easier.
Stunned with the implications of what Romirez has said, l a robot Conor serves the meal.  His eyes never leave Romi who digs hungrily into the food.
Hmm, que rico.  What is it you call this?
Pheasant.
You Scots have a way with game.  It still has life in it. Spirit.  Back home the food is so...domestic.
Why are you here?
I was sent by his majesty of Spain to Inverness as a con- sultant on matters of metal.
You're a long way from Inverness.
In my travels I heard the story of the MacLeod boy struck down and brought from the hand of death by powers not of this Earth.
You know me home.  Me name.
It was time for our paths to cross.
Romirez pulls back the sleeve on his cloak.
You see this?
He traces some discoloration on his arm.
When I was a boy a cart driven by a drunken fool crushed me.  All thought I would die or be maimed for life.  But I healed quickly. And like you I paid the price for being different.
You are the same?
Do you ever feel a flow, as if some- thing were pushing against you?
Yes.  Always.
Does it change with me in the room?
It is less.
You feel you know me.
I don't know why.
We are brothers.
Romirez and Conor walk alone amongst torch-lit hutches.
He told me there could be only one.

Some cling to sanity through time with the one continuity and trad0 ition their lives have known: The Game. (Conor confused) You and I Conor, we are different from all others around us.  You know this, you can feel it.  We are flesh and bone like any man, but unlike our neighbors we are rather difficult to injure, (looks away) permanently.
I don't understand.
You are still so very young.
I'm twenty-two.
(shakes head) Not even a single lifetime.
Romirez chooses his words very carefully.
Conor, you and I, we cannot be killed.
What?
We are immortal.
Stunned, Conor backs away from Romirez.
No, that can't be.
Romirez grasps Conor's shoulder.
It is as you are.
(pushes away) No!
This is all too much for Conor.
Listen to me.  Hear the words.
This is madness!
It is the truth.
No!

Romirez suddenly draws his sword and thrusts it into Cono heart.  The boy's mouth drops open in shocked terror as h eyes roll up into his head. A shudder, then Conor slides off the blade and crashes to ground.
Brenna stops her car in front of the Washington Police De ment.  Getting out of her car she climbs the stairs but s After a moment of indecision she changes her mind and ret to her car.
Brenna lowers herself wearily into a chair, rubs her eyes and stares absently out the window. Reaching across to an end table, she plays back her answe machine. Beep.
This is Dr. Wickland at GWU.  Your test came back today.  You can call me here at the med center if you have any questions.
Click. Beep.
Brenna, where the hell are you? The place is full of cops asking weird questions.  What's going on? I've got work stacking up.  Get in here right away.
Brenna stands and goes to the kitchen, returning with a g of wine. Click. Beep.
Brenna.
She freezes in her tracks.
My quarrel is not with you.  Meet me.
Brenna's eyes are glued on the machine.
We have much to talk of, you and I.  Answers for the young historian. (beat) O'Reily's.  Tonight.  I've grown to like taverns.
Click. Beep.
(singing) Happy birthday to you, happy birth- day to you, happy birthday dear Brenna, happy birthday to you.
Brenna is still upset from the last call.

Hi Brenna, it's mom.  Me and your neices just wanted to call and wish you a happy birthday.  Crissy made a real cute card for you, be sure to call her.  Will you be home for Easter?  Call when you can.  Love you.
Click. Hiss.

This HISS of Brenna's answering machine becomes the HISS cooking.  Bandaged about the chest, Conor asleep on his cot. Suddenly he sits up.  Sweating.  He looks about the room confusion as Romirez enters with a plate of food.
Three days you've laid there. It's time you ate.
(dazed) This can't be.
You are not dead, boy.  Accept it.
This is monstrous.  I'll burn in hell for all eternity.
You'd have to die first. (extends forkful of food) Aqui.
Conor starts CRYING.
What is to become of me?  Am I to wander the Earth forever like a ghost?
You will live.  Survive.
Then they were right.  I am evil. This is God's punishment.
You have done nothing wrong Conor MacLeod.
Oh my God.  Oh my God I'm lost.
Two days later. Nearly healed, Conor and Romirez stand near a quietly mov stream.
Why does he want to kill me?
You recall how I spoke of the push you feel and how I make it less?
Aye.

It is always less with my living. Far or near.  But if I were to die the push would become stronger than ever before.  There is power in this.  And as long as you and I live, The Knight can never have it all.
But we cannot be killed.
There is an imperfection.  For all your healing, if your head ever leaves your neck, you are dead. You can survive anything but steel against your threat.  Then it is over.  The end.
How can I stop such a man?
Hide.  Run to the ends of the Earth till you learn.  You must learn to defend yourself.  In this I can help.
Why?
We are brothers.  And you are a defense- (beat) -of sorts.
An old man, MR. NORTH, leads Taupin up the drive of a rur farmhouse somewhere in the hinterland of Pennsylvania.
When your father died I saw to it that the grounds were kept up.
The money in the estate was enough to cover your costs?
Oh yes, more than enough.
Furniture clad in white sheets.  Dust everywhere.
Most of the furniture was put into protective storage.  I'll have some boys come up and clean the place out for you.
Taupin drags a finger across a dusty window pane.
(fascinated) You're one of William's kids, huh?
His only kid.
Sure take after him.  Never seen a father and son look more alike.
We were very close.
The resemblance is amazing.
When may I expect the cleaners?
I'll send them right up.

Coupled strangers gyrate under colored lights and recorde Brenna sits alone.  Whatever nervousness she brought thro door with her has been turned into a comfortable cynicism the three empty glasses in front of her.
With something less than perfect coordination, sits down her.
That stuff'll put you away if you're not careful.

There was a Count.  Count Dusan.  He would invite the local peasants to his chateau, fill them full of wine, then slice their bellies so he could reuse it. (smiles) The symmetry of that somehow always appealed to me.
You're very macabre.
It's my birthday.
Happy birthday.
Thanks.
Brenna drains her glass and sets it down with a sigh.
Buy a birthday girl a drink?
A small neighborhood tavern.  Regulars chat amicably with BARTENDER-OWNER.
Sits alone at a corner table.  A WAITRESS hovers over him
Lager and lime.

Taupin's lager is drained.  Lost in thought, he drags a f around and around the lip of the mug. He hand stops.  It twitches.  Shakes. Taupin pulls his hand from the glass and watches it shake out of control.  A warning. He WHIRLS around suddenly to see LING KAHN, Asian, standi over him.
MacLeod.
Taupin is anxious, poised for attack. Kahn breaks into a broad smile.
Spare a chair?
Kahn?
Are you going to offer me a chair or leave me standing here all night?
Sit.
Kahn takes his place across the table.
(unsure) How are you?
Head still secure to the neck.
How did you find me?
How many places this side of the Atlantic serve lager and lime?
Taupin looks to his own glass.
Old habits die hard. (to waitress) Waitress!  A round of Nitzhic! (beat) Peasant drool, I know.  But it's the closest thing they stock to my side of the fence.
What are you doing here?
It is the gathering, my friend.  The settling of old scores.
Taupin tenses.
And have you something to settle with me?
(smiles) Not tonight.  Tonight I have a drink with an old friend.
It's good to see you, Kahn.
The waitress sets down two glasses.
Come, toast with me the past. (raises glass) To old conquests, old loves, and to a time when we cared about either.
Kahn drains his glass.
Waitress!
Kahn and Taupin sit drunkedly on the marble steps of a cl government building.
I'll never forget the look on that Papal commander's face when his "heretic stronghold" turned out to be a rock full of whores climbing all over Neuvich.
Neuvich, the clown of the crusades.

But then rides up Pope Pius who calmly brushes the dust from his papal cross, climbs off his papal horse, draws his papal sword and asks just what the hell is going on.  And what did Neuvich, dear dear drunken Neuvich do?
Offered the Pope one of his whores.
They LAUGH. A JOGGER stops on the gravel and listens to the strange c
Had a great swing with his blade. For a Pope.
(sighs) Good times then.  A man could stretch his legs without bring- ing half the world down around his ears.  Not like now.
The jogger shakes his head and runs on.
(serious) He found us even there.
He always did.
A CLINKING of chain link as Taupin and Kahn climb a fence tumble into the Washington Zoo.
I haven't drunk this much since-
-Since you last saw me.
Kahn chucks an empty wine bottle.  An unspecified animal sleepily somewhere in the darkness.
Come on.
Taupin and Kahn stumble through an open-air display of As animals.  Their VOICES seem to echo everywhere.
I love zoos.  Ever since I was a kid.
You were never a kid.
Kahn leans on the wall of a water buffalo pen.
(points at one) I knew his great-grandfather.
You're insane.
No, seriously.  We used to shoot pool together in Rangoon.
How do you do it, Kahn?  How do you live so full of life for so long?
Tasting and enjoying life is the only thing of value we have.  All else is just marking time. (beat) You're marking time.
I've had a few more concerns.
Kahn jams his hands into his overcoat and starts down the
The pressure only comes when you let the taste slip into your mouth.
You're wrong.
You don't run as hard, MacLeod. You just don't run as hard anymore.
Late.  The bar is nearly empty. No sign of the Knight.  Brenna looks at her watch, sighs, drops a bill onto the counter.

Brenna has left the bar and is now walking down a dimly l street. She hears something and turns. -Nothing.  A breeze rustles the trees above. After only a few more paces she hears something again. Brenna abruptly turns. -Right into the face of THE KNIGHT. Brenna SCREAMS.  The Knight reaches into his leather carr

Exit a facing townhouse.  The Knight removes his hand fro bag as they spill onto the sidewalk LAUGHING and YELLING. Brenna moves close to the group as they walk to the corne The Knight follows at a measured distance. At the corner the teenagers climb into a pickup and drive Brenna bolts into the intersection.  Weaving through SCRE brakes, she disappears into a pair of lighted glass doors
40 well dressed PATRONS, numbered cards pinned to their l sit in velvetly plush surroundings.  At the front of the stands a thin moustached art AUCTIONEER. Brenna BUSTLES in from outside.
I apoligize for the lateness of the hour, but I'm sure you will all agree the quality of this year's collection is well worth the time.
The Knight BURSTS in with his leather carrying bag.  Bren slides along the draped back wall to avoid him.
(holding statuette) For this fine example of medieval religious art, let us open the bid at 4,000 dollars.
The Knight closes in on Brenna casually, without hurry.
Brenna raises her arm to attract the attention of a SECUR GUARD..
(points at Brenna) 11,000.  A bid at 11,000.
No, I-

The guard notices she has no lapel number and starts for very officially. Being closed in on from both sides, Brenna suddenly runs the room to a fire exit, setting off an ALARM as she flie the door. The Knight leaps after her, knocking over an OLD WOMAN in front row.
Brenna runs the sidewalk and disappears into a Metro stat
Brenna runs down the platform and jumps into a subway car just as the doors shut.
is also now on the platform but can only watch Brenna thr a window as the train pulls away.
Brenna KNOCKS at the front door.  No answer. She KNOCKS harder.  The unlatched door pushes open.
Brenna stands in the doorway. Before her is a disaster.  Furniture has been smashed lik matchsticks.  A desk drawer's contents lie strewn in pile the floor. Brenna enters slowly.
Mr. Taupin?  I have to talk to you.

Nothing has been left unturned or unbroken. Brenna kneels and sifts through a pile of crumpled papers She comes across an old black and white photograph.  Badl streaked and faded, it shows Taupin standing beside a far house.  Written in the corner is "Worstick, 1928". Brenna slips the photo into her pocket.  Standing, she tu smack into Taupin.
Finished?
He looks past her to the destruction of his living room. doesn't seem to surprise him.
He tried to kill me last night.
Where?
Dupont Circle.
Taupin sifts through the debris, selecting articles from
Who is he?
At the moment?  Carl Smith.
And you?
He ignores the question.
What will you do now?
You needn't worry Miss Cartwright. I've been at this a very long time.
He called you "MacLeod".
Not your concern.
I left a man dead in Felton.  But you don't really care, do you?
That bothers you?
He was innocent.
He's dead.  Whatever I may or may not feel means exceedingly little to him now.
What about me?
You?
I'm a witness to a murder.  That seems to put me pretty high on your friend's chop list.
Have you gone to the police?
No.
Why not?  I'm sure they'd love to hear your story.
I'd rather hear yours.
(beat) You are being foolish.
I'm a historian, Mr. Taupin. Only once in a lifetime do you stare history in the face.
Go home.
He walks to the doorway.
Why does he want to kill you?
Taupin stops, his back to her.
He sees me as a threat.
Are you?
Taupin walks out the door.
On a clear rise above the village Romirez and Conor spar swords covered in heavy cloth.  Conor is having difficult
Concentrate!
Conor thrusts.  Romirez blocks.
Harder.  Concentrate harder.
Me arm hurts.
Again.  Try again.
Conor strikes.  Romirez easily blocks.
Harder!  You swing like an impotent cow!
Go to hell.
Oh, the boy has a mouth, now if only he had an arm.
Ticked off, Conor leans himself into a two-fisted swing. Romirez knocks it aside, but Conor recovers faster than h knocking Romirez flat on his back.
Impotent cow.
Muy Bien!
Conor drops the sword and wipes the sweat from his face. Romirez pours wine from a leather bag into a goblet pulle from his belt.  He offers it to Conor.
Here my boy, from vineyards as sweet and smooth as a young girl's thigh.
Conor accepts the cup.  Romirez pulls himself to his feet
It will take less effort as you learn.
It's like to kill me first.
Romirez puts his arm around Conor and refills his cup.
You have a gift.  One you must protect.
And what is this great gift that cannot be seen or smelt?
The Fabric of life.  The spark that allows the passing of existence from one generation to another.
(shakes head) If that was meant to be an ex- planation Mr. Romirez from Spain, I'm afraid you've failed.
Romirez put his arm around Conor and leads him away.
Come.  Enough sword play for an afternoon.

A friendly horse race.  Their reflections bouncing off a glen, Conor and Romirez dodge moss-laiden ruts and leap f tree trunks. Beaming, Conor pushes through a last turn and stops to wa for Romirez, several lengths behind.
(as Romirez rides up) You're no match for Scot, Mr. Romirez.  We're raised as riders.
Point conceeded, Mr. MacLeod.
Both their eyes turn to the beauty in view.  Romirez pull leaf from a tree and studies it closely.
What is the fascinatioon?  It is only a leaf.
All living things pay dues, Conor.  They must be respected for that.
He pulls the leaf's points from the stalk, one by one.
As they age they contribute to a sum that is the kindling from which all future life comes.  To feel it, to know it, is to be in touch with the will of every living thing.
I do not think I like the sound of that.

It does not feel nearly as frightening as it sounds.  But the consequences of such feelings can be very frightening. For it gives you great strength.  The strength of _knowledge_.  The ability to stand between the giving of what has always been to what will always be.
I feel hardly nothing.
You have not been fully trained. But you will learn.  And you will be good, I can feel that.  You have apt- itude.  This is why our friend is so concerned.
But why be so concerned about me?
This power is divided amongst you, me, and others like cuts in a pie. But the cuts are not equal.  Some, like you and he, have more.  Much more.
And you?
I am a small player.  But if by helping you I can keep that monster from being the last, then perhaps my life has meant something.
I am not ready for this.

You must be.  You have responsibilities. You must learn the rules.  You can never attract attention to yourself, never show the side that will draw others to you.  You will always know when you are in the presence of another.  Beware. But more importantly Conor MacLeod, will be your battle against time.  In the coming years you will see kingdoms rise then rot like wheat.  People will become a transitory, pathetic lot.  The only constant you will know will be the others and the tradition their greed and quest represent.  But life without morality, without the ability to truly taste the sweetness of wine and love, is no life at all.  That is how the others exist.  Nothing more than walking corpses living only to slaughter each other in an insane quest to be the last.  Keep your soul sewed to the earth.  Do not become one of them.
Of course.
You are young, inexperienced.  You do not know what time can do.  How it can sap all pity, all love.
That is not me.
With the proper tools, Conor, a naive man can be much more dangerous than an evil one.
Conor!
A VILLAGER approaches from across the pasture.
Yes, Darin.
Hate to be bothering you like this, but me mare threw a shoe.
Conor looks to Romirez.
Go ahead, Senor. (gestures to wine) I have my friend to keep me company.
I'll be back when I can.
Conor sets off across the pasture.

Romirez enters and flops onto a cot. Settling down for a nap, he sets his sword beneath the be and closes his eyes to the distant sound of CHILDREN play The room is still. Romirez begins to drowse. Suddenly his eyes leap open with full alertness. His hand moves under the cot. With an EXPLOSION the front door is lifted from its hinge and splintered into fragments.  Passing through a cloud o sawdust enters the Knight.  Without pause he topples a ki shelf onto a supine Romirez.
Romirez.  What a surprise.
Romirez is struggling under the debris. The Knight thrusts hard onto an exposed leg. The limb is severed.
Madonna!
The Knight begins casting aside the shelving. With lightning speed Romirez pulls the sword from beneath bed and hammers it deep into the Knight's side.
Bastard!

He crashes back against the wall. Romirez tries to lift himself from the bed using his swor as a crutch. The Knight has regained a meager balance on his knees. Blood pours from the slice in his stomach, Romirez pushes himself across the bed, plants his sword i the floor and hobbles a few paces before collapsing.
Oh, Santa Maria!
The Knight crawls across the bed and drops to his knees beside Romirez.
Why run?
Demonio!
The Knight's trembling hands raise his shaking sword high
To hell with you.
Conor pounds at a horseshoe. The hammer slips from his grasp as he slumps forward as i pushed.
Badly wounded, the Knight staggers through the shattered doorway and tumbles into the street. A CHILD SCREAMS. Pulling himself up, the Knight hobbles away.
Conor is running through the village.

Conor rushes in and shudders to a stop. An entire wall is showered with blood. Conor walks slowly forward.  Dazed. As he looks down something takes his attention. It is Romirez's severed head. Conor moans in anguish and drops to his knees on the bloo stained floor. His head sinks to his chest as he begins sobbing.
Somewhere in the bowels of the museum, the RESEARCH LIBRARIAN, a wiry young man, sits at his cluttered desk. Brenna looms above him.
Come on Brenna, your ass is already in a sling, don't drag me into it.
All I need is for you to check the name.
You talked to your supervisor lately?  He's burning up the place about you just dropping out of sight.  That on top of the cops bugging him.
I'll take care of that Corey, but I need this now.
The librarian looks her over skeptically.
Corey, you _owe_ me.
It's that important?
Yeah.
The librarian reluctantly reaches for his keys.
Holding Brenna's photograph, the research librarian is co ing through stained binders.  The room is old, disorganiz and gives the impression that every fact worth knowing mu be in it somewhere.
Wilson know about this?
I'm doing it on my own.
Good way to lose your job.
Some job.  Card filing and cabinet dusting.  Four years in this dump and I haven't written anything for Wilson that a wounded yak couldn't do.
I liked the bit you did about Baltic chastity belts. Too bad no one else did.
It's bullshit.  Everything. My job, the people I get involved with, I'm up to here with it.
You always were hard to impress.
The librarian pulls a binder and opens it.
Who is it?
Not who.  What.  Worstick's a town in Pennsylvania.
Brenna enters and sits at her desk.  She is looking for something.
(confused) Chris, have you seen my notebook?
Chris is seated at the desk next to her.  He points at th supervisor's door.
Why, that son of a bitch.
The high backed office chair is spun away from an angry, entering Brenna.
What's wrong Wilson, huh?  Not enough excitement in your own desk?  What the hell were you looking for in mine?
The chair turns.  Detective Moran, not her supervisor, le through her notebook.
A murder.
You better have a warrant.  That's my notebook, you've got no right to be sticking your fingers into it.
I've got a morgue filling up with bodies.  That's my right.
What do you want from me?

Well, the man of the hour that we all would like to talk to about now has apparently skipped town. (looks at notebook) And all of a sudden the Smithsonian's ambulence chaser is an expert on missing persons.
Brenna lifts the telephone receiver.
I'm calling an attorney.
You and I should talk first.
We've got nothing to say.
Moran presses the post on the phone.
What are you going to tell them?  That you're protecting a man who's killed four people?
Four?
All fashionably without heads.
Spare me the details.

But there's more.  Wednesday someone played javelin with the cemetary curator in Felton, Delaware.  Some locals spotted two cars with D.C. plates and surprise surprise, they turn out to be registered to our own Brenna Cartwright and the ever popular Richard Taupin.
What are you getting at, Moran?

You've been a busy little beaver. Especially with that records mess up in Church Hill. (looks at notebook) Your notes are very complete. Naturally my feelings were crushed when you didn't rush right over and tell us what you knew. (looks up) In fact, we're considering book- ing the ambulence chaser as an accessory to murder.
It'll never stick.
But we might just give it the 'ole college try.  What with the court back ups, it could be days before you got an arraignment. But then, I'm sure the flunk-out neice of the D.A. knows all about that.
You're an asshole, Moran.
I want Taupin.
What makes you so sure he's the one?
Just for laughs we raided wonder boy's house.  There was a gallon of one of the corpse's blood in his carpet.  I think it was about then I withdrew his name for humanitarian of the year.
What's all of this got to do with me?
What were you doing in Felton?
Research.  If your pal was there I never saw him.
I have witnesses that can put the two of you together.
(knows he's bluffing) Never take up poker, Detective.
Don't be stupid, lady.  Your neck can be sliced as fast as anyone else's.
Brenna reaches across and lifts her notebook.
Why don't you wait until it comes out in paperback?
Moran watches her leave.  He lifts the telephone receiver
Striding out into the corridor, Brenna passes Dennis, the from her bedroom, leaning against the doorway.
I warned you.
Go to hell.

A PRIEST celebrates mass in a present-day cathedral. In the rear of the church apart from the other PARISHIONE sits the Knight.  As the priest leads the parishioners th the procession of faith, the Knight alone repeats it quie to himself in Latin, the ancient language of the church.
Crooked tombstones strewn across the bleached ground of a not beloning to reality. In full medieval tartan, Conor stands against a forceful

Run the length plain, spewing forth steam and staggering SKELETONS.  There are dozens of them, all carrying their under one arm. The skeletons press forward and trap Conor against the tr of a dead oak.  The heads break into harsh, demonic LAUGH Conor puts his hands over his ears in pain as the bodies forward. SCREAMING, he disappears under a mass of gleaming bones.
Taupin wakes from the dream with a SHOUT. He has fallen asleep in a desk chair. Taupin walks to a window and looks out to the green hills the distance.
Brenna's sedan shoots down a country highway.
Checking her rear view mirror, Brenna notices two suspici FIGURES in a car behind her.
Brenna pulls to the side.  The car from behind passes wit incident.
Brenna is driving again.  Listening now to the RADIO, she casts a glance in the mirror.  The same car is behind her
Passing over a rise in the highway, Brenna turns abruptly onto a service road and behind a group of trees.
Pauses a moment at the intersection, then drives on.
Brenna shows the PROPRIETOR the photograph.  He explains something to her. Brenna steps outside the store onto the Main Street of th very small community of Worstick.
Brenna passes a small monument settled in a flower bed. a plaque memorializing five locals murdered in 1931.
A mile out of town Brenna stops at a farmhouse.  She chec it against the photo she found at Taupin's townhouse.  Th match.
Brenna KNOCKS.
You shouldn't have come.
Brenna whirls around and sees Taupin behind her.
We're you followed?
He looks to the road.
No.
No one knows you're here?
No.  I had to talk to you.
You had to do _nothing_!
You're wrong.
You're a fool.
Maybe.
Pause.  Taupin strides through the doorway.
Come inside.
Brenna and Taupin enter.  A heavy broad sword sits on the coffee table.
Is this what you killed them with?
You've been listening to rumors.
Our cars were seen together in Felton.  They're calling me an accessory to murder.
You are.  Now.
Beat.  They're stuck with each other.
There's several bedrooms down the hall.  Take your pick.
The room is a strange decor.  18th century paintings hang beside grotesque medieval carvings. Brenna's face softens with worry.  What is she doing?
A plain-clothed POLICE OFFICER is in mid conversation.
No, that's the last place we saw her.  Okay, will do.
He hangs up.
Well?
(shrugs) We keep looking.
Wonderful.
Taupin sits at his desk.  Before him is spread out blank certificates, driver licenses and title deeds.  His eyes to the corridor where Brenna is.  An idea has come to him Brenna enters.
What's all that?
Richard Taupin has become cumbersome.  It would be best if he just disappeared.
Brenna walks to the window.
You did kill those men.
Not all of them.
When you finish, what then?
I go my way and you can write all you want about the big bad Mr. Taupin.
You make it all sound so simple.

The only real difficulty comes in changing over the ownership of property I've aquired.  That requires certain records and most importantly a personal appearance at the county seat in Gettysburg.  But that's where you come in.
You want me to front for you.
The less exposure I recieve around government buildings the better.  You, as Mrs. Taupin, will attract considerably less attention than I.
Brenna is unsure.
Not such a bad trade.  The story of a lifetime for a few days work?
Detective Moran looks through the broken remains of the l room. An INSPECTOR enters.
They lost her outside of Thurmont.
Moran sighs and tosses a piece of wood on the pile of deb
I want people in here to check over every piece of this stuff.
Figure she's with him?
Yeah.
We ran down that Church Hill info. She's right.  There is no Richard Taupin.
Any other I.D.s come up?
Not yet.  Called FBI yesterday. Thompson's going to try CIA this afternoon. (shrugs) Y'never know.
Moran rises and dons his coat.
Should have seen him the first night.  Son of a bitch stood there with a quart of blood on his pant leg and didn't even blink.
You'd think he'd had practice.
Moran walks to the door.
I think he has.
Conor, now MAJOR DUPONT of the French infantry, pours ove battle plans. An AIDE, dressed as Conor-Dupont in 18th century European military garb, enters the command area.
The men are assembled, Major.
A GENERAL stands beside the major.
See that they are indeed ready, Dupont.
Yes General.
A regiment of INFANTRYMEN, pale blue coat tails tossing i the light breeze, stand at attention. A STAFF SARGEANT presents the men to Dupont.
Regiment ready for review, sir.
Dupont walks past the sargeant to the line.
(to soldier) Stand straight, you are a soldier of the King.
Yes sir.

Dupont continues down the line.  Another soldier's infant jacket is almost hilariously mis-buttoned, one collar sti up four inches higher than the other. Dupont with both hands rips open the soldier's coat, spra brass buttons onto the ground. He moves on.
(to soldier) Where is your bayonet?
Lost it sir.
Where?
The soldier hedges.
You heard the Major!  Where!
Whorehouse sir.
Dupont's face softens in exasperation, then toughens.
Your rifle.  Hand it to me.
The soldier obeys.  Dupont inspects the firing mechanism.
The flint is cracked.  No spark will reach your powder.  You will die tomorrow.
He throws the rifle roughly back into the soldier's hands

Tomorrow you go to _battle_!  And you look like children! (beat) The General has charged me with seeing that you are prepared, and prepared you will be!  If necessary you stand here all night!  Sargeant!
The sargeant leaps to attention.
Yes sir.
See to it.
Yes sir.

Dupont turns briskly, then stops abruptly as if alerted b thing.  He whirls around and faces the young infantrymen. His expression is quizzical as he walks the line, checkin each face carefully. One PRIVATE seizes his attention.  The private is cautiou
Your name?
Mulet.
It is as if Dupont knows him.  The two stare at each othe Dupont turns and leaves.
Inside a small farmhouse commandeered for officer's quart Dupont (Conor) and several others eat their evening meal. A CAPTAIN finishes his story.
(amused) ...And what a sight!  That old mare just kept falling over her own guts till someone finally shot her.
The OFFICERS LAUGH.  All but Dupont.
(beside Dupont) Complete your inspection?
They're nothing but boys.  It will be a slaughter tomorrow.
(laughs) I doubt much can change that. The enemy has five brigades waiting for us.
We need more time.
Won't get it. (shrugs) We are a sacrifice.  A diversion.
Dupont pokes unenthusiastically at his plate.
Eat up Dupont.  It will probably be your last.
(rises) Not likely.
Dupont goes to the window.  Dusk shines orange on his fac In the foreground the man Dupont encountered at the line- Mulet, is chopping firewood.
Several hours later. Most are asleep.  Mulet continues his wood splitting. From out of the dark cottage steps Dupont.
I thought I gave orders the regiment was to drill.
Staff sargeant detailed me to prepare firewood for the break- fast cooking.
What is your position?
Second musketeer.
I understand you joined up in Bremen.
You seem to understand a great deal.
I am a Major, Private.  You would do well remembering that when addressing me.
Excuse me, "sir".  I thought we spoke as equals.
Equals?
(shrugs) If you wish to play games, Major.
Mulet returns to his chore.
Wait.  I think we understand each other.
We have no understanding.
Then it is time two of us did. You are very young.  I was once young.  I can help.
Mulet LAUGHS.
Help?  I've seen others "help". Somehow a head always ended up on the counter.
It can be different.  It must be.
It never changes, Major.
Mulet turns to his chore.  Dupont grabs his arm.
We must talk.
(shakes him off) Stay out of it.
(angry) Don't threaten me, Private.

(disgust) Who do you think I am?  One of your freckle faced children waiting to die tomorrow?  "Threaten you"?  You and I just living will always be a threat.  Forever.  Look at your life, Major.  Look at mine.  Nothing there but threat.  Threats and nothingness. It's what we live for.
Mulet turns his back on Dupont. Dupont draws his cutlass.
Do not turn your back on me.
You are really going to force this, aren't you?
Either you are with me or against me.
Mulet turns slowly, axe in hand.
Have I a choice?
The two stare into eyes empty of emotion. Mulet's hand flinches.  An attack? Dupont CUTS quickly, slicing open both of Mulet's arms. The axe drops to the ground. Mulet seems strangely calm.
You see Major?  You are not so different.
Dupont cuts off Mulet's head where he stands.
Dupont drags the corpse across the meadow and dumps it in a swamp.
It is very late.  Only a few OFFICERS are seated in the p Dupont tries to concentrate on prayer, but is distracted.
(voice flashback) You see Major?  You are not so different...
I had no choice.
Dupont sighs and looks to the altar.
Who am I deceiving?
Certainly not me.
Dupont whirls around to see the Knight, dressed as he in sitting one row behind. Dupont leaps to his feet.
You needn't look so flushed, Major.  You are quite safe in church.
Dupont eases his breathing.
State of grace and all that.
Tradition.
It's all we have.
Dupont has backed up a few paces.
All this time and still a scared little boy.
Dupont sits down.
Not so scared.
Perhaps not. (smiles) You seem to have misplaced a private.  No doubt by now his head is stranger to his neck.
No doubt.
You surprise me.  Eliminating a rival like that.  Such are the actions of a man of conquest.  I was mistaken.  300 years have turned the boy's fear into ambit- ion.
You're wrong.

I know you very well, Conor MacLeod. And I can see the truth beginning to make itself clear to you.  Mulet, Romirez, they were fools without vision.  It was destined that the board would be cleared for the real players.
The Knight almost seems proud of Dupont.
Romirez understood.  Not you.
Romirez is dust.
The Knight looks to the altar.
Finish your prayers?
Finish yours?
(smiles) Our common heritage. (beat) I am your only real friend, you know.  The only one who truly understands you. (rises) I look forward to the day we meet again.  And I kill you.
So sure?
The Knight leans forward and puts his face very near.
You can't stay in church forever.
The Knight moves into the aisle.
Good night, Major.
He exits. Conor sits in the dim church alone.  Very alone.
Richard Taupin sits against the stone of an old Catholic Taupin sighs.  A long, weary sigh.
Taupin and Brenna sit at a table working on forms. Taupin looks up from his work and studies Brenna's face w malice.

Brenna and Taupin are taking a walk along the township's outskirts. Crossing a small bridge over a smaller creek, they encoun the elderly caretaker Mr. North and his eight year old GR Both with fishing poles.
Morning Mr. North
Same.
Such a pretty day.  If I live to be 90 I'll never tire of mornings like this.  Mind you I'm 74 now.
No.
Yes sir.  When you get older your priorities change.  It's the simple things that count.  Without them growing old can be a very lonely thing.
I'm sure that's true.
The grandson is having difficulty baiting his line.  Taup down beside the young fisherman.
(takes worm) Here.  The hook should go just below the head, where the meat is toughest.
Thanks.
Taupin's show of affection surprises Brenna.
Show you a trick.
Taupin takes a clump of leaves from the bridge and winds around the hook.
Fish are creatures of habit.  They like their food where they're used to it.  At the top, hiding in old leaves.
Where did you learn that?
My father taught me.
Your father must be smart.
Yes, he was.
Brenna is touched.
Brenna lies on her bed thinking.  She puts on a robe and into the living room.
Taupin sits before the fireplace, its flames reflecting o brandy glass.  Brenna moves quietly to a seat beside him.

(eyes on the fireplace) There was a man once.  Just a simple woodcarver.  But he understood.  More than anyone he could see to the heart of it. (beat) It never ends.  Today is the same as the first.  Tomorrow will be the same as today.  So much time.  And all of it wasted. (beat) You love history?
Yes.
I wish I could.
Brenna looks through a property zoning book.
Walking past small town stores, Brenna allows herself a m to window shop.
Is a small poster advertising a community get-together. peels it off the glass and slips it into her notebook.
Brenna and Taupin go over various forms and documents.
The estate stuff is pretty straight forward.  Just lots of forms and an appearance at the county seat.
It will take some time for the forms to clear before you go to Gettysburg.
Brenna is silent.
Second thoughts?
Pause.
No. (beat) So what now?  We just wait?
Yes.
Well, as long as we're stuck here.
She hands him the poster from earlier.
It's some sort of party the town is throwing.
They do it each year.
I thought it might be a nice break from all of this.
Taupin stacks the documents into a folder.
Maybe it would do us both good.
There's a catch.  You're supposed to wear 19th century clothing.
Taupin is going through an old trunk.
My father was something of a junk collector.
He comes across a long period dress and offers it to Bren
Here, try this.  I suppose they're still making women the same as back then.
It's beautiful.
A little dusty.
Taupin fishes through the trunk and comes up with an old hat.  He turns it over in his hand with stoic memory.

Conor and a beautiful young woman, KATHERINE, sit on the steps in 1800s period dress.  Other young COUPLES relax n enjoying the warm summer's twilight.  Katherine's MOTHER between the couples offering lemonade, cakes, and the lik
Do it again.
She is thoroughly charmed by Conor.
All right.
Conor wraps a length of yarn about his fingers.  By turni hand over and bending his knuckles just so, the web becom outline of a lion..
A lion. (growls)
Katherine is delighted. Conor starts to remove the yarn.  Katherine touches his a
Oh please.  Another one.
What would you like?
Something pretty.
Like you.
Conor cups his hands, bends his fingers, and comes up wit four leaf clover.
That's wonderful.  Where did you ever learn it?
Far away.
Kiss me.
Conor shoots a glance for the mother, then kisses Katheri softly.
(o.s.) You'll be leaving the girl alone.
A YOUNG MAN stands a few yards from the stairs.
David.
Do you have cause to bothering us?
That's my girl.
David, we've already spoken of this.
He's not what he pretends to be.
Conor climbs to his feet.
You best leave, son.
You think you're so high and mighty, coming into town and taking a man's woman.  Well I know about you.  I know about the things you do.
(moving closer) I said you best leave.
You'd like that, wouldn't you? (to Katherine) Ask him about his friends.  The ones he meets in the town square. Ask him about the blade he keeps beneath his bed.
Conor grabs the youth's collar and pulls him close.
(like ice) Leave.  While you still can.
The youth pushes away from the grasp.
You don't frighten me.
I should.

The young man throws a fist at Conor.  It is easily block Conor returns with a savage blow to the chest that knocks the young man gasping onto the ground. Katherine runs up behind and grabs Conor's outstretched a
No!  Leave him.  Please don't hurt him. Please.
COUGHING painfully, the youth climbs to his feet and stag away.
He's not what you think.
He turns and runs down the road.
He's not what you think!
Katherine turns to Conor, his face still locked in ice.
I don't care who you are or where you come from.
She hugs him tightly.
I love you.
Conor's face softens as he brings up an arm to hold her.

An auditorium has been transformed with colored lights an strung paper into a small town party. TEENAGERS in period dress control the floor, dancing to a decidedly un-period ROCK BAND. The OLDER GUESTS are gathered around the punch bowl talki crops or Pennsylvania politics.
Fitted as well as can be expected in her lace dress, ente with Taupin, himself dressed in a formal suit complete wi His clothes fit perfectly. Mr. North, comically dressed as a pirate, greets them.
Mr. Taupin!  Glad you could make it. Best get some punch before it's gone.  Near the whole valley showed up.
They go to the table. Taupin pours a glass of punch.  An ELDERLY WOMAN approach
If I didn't know better I'd say William Taupin.
His son.  Richard.
Mr. Taupin is up from Washington to look over his father's estate.
Your father died some years ago. This is your first visit?
The tone is snide.
Of sorts.
I suppose a Taupin had to show up eventually. (walks away)
Good evening, Mrs. Butler.
She turns in surprise at his knowing her name, then walks
What was all that about?
Sorry Mr. Taupin.  That's not meant for you.  Just some didn't take much to your father.
Why?
My father was never one for social whirls.
Kept to himself for sure.  Then with all that business in '31.
What business?

Family down the road from the Taupin place was murdered.  All cut up they were.  Horrible.  Two strangers were also found with the bodies.  No one ever accused William, but with his reputation as a loner and the rumors about him and some of the wives in town, folks just never forgot.  Most were relieved when they heard he'd died.  Sorry Mr. Taupin.
Nothing to be sorry about.
Just your pappy scared some.
The rock band finished as a PORTLY MAN in a union soldier uniform takes the microphone.
All right, the kids have had their fun.  Now it's time for a little more traditional dancing.
The rock band gives ground to a group of older MUSICIANS. a nod from the union soldier they begin a folk tune with and hammer dulcimer. The costumed guests take to the floor.
I don't know any of these.  I'll make a fool of myself.
Follow me.
Taupin starts into it with perfect grace.  A faltering Br tries to keep up.
William Taupin seems to have left his mark.
Yes.
And you are William Taupin, aren't you?
Yes.
They do a final turn and finish.  The other DANCERS appla
You're using your son's name.
No.  Just the child of some lonely girl I gave a ride to.  When they died I put them in a grave with my name on it. Twenty years later I became the son.
Brenna is staring at him.
More punch?
He leads her to a table.
Then you must be at least 70 years old.
At least.
That's impossible.
Several of the ELDERLY WOMEN are watching Taupin from acr the room.
A bus with "Gettysburg" across the front pulls to a stop a dark terminal.  A lone passenger steps off into the mis It is the Knight, bound up in a leather jacket and carryi only a long, narrow case.
Brenna and Taupin walk alone in the night outside the hal
It's frightening sometimes the way you talk about other people's lives.
A factor of age.
I hope I never get that old.
You won't.
Brenna pulls away.
I must be insane.  Leaving work, ditching cops.  All to follow a murderer.  A very old murderer, but a murderer just the same.
Why are you here?
I've been telling myself it's the award winning journal article I'm going to write.  But it's not. (looks at him squarely) It's you.
I see.
I'm not even sure why.
Hardly a reason to run off with a murderer.
My life has been chock full of people with complications and weak- nesses.  I can't stand it.  But you're different.  It's in your hands.  A clarity.
You are a very perceptive young woman.
Just a little crazy.
A thoughtful pause.
Miss Cartwright, it's time I showed you something.
Taupin and Brenna descend the stairs to a seemingly flush Taupin reaches behind a bookcase and pulls something.  A from his hand and the wall becomes a doorway.
(gestures to interior) Miss Cartwright?
Brenna steps uneasily into the darkness.  Taupin follows switches on the light.

Brenna's expression changes to awe. The room is massive, a cross between a museum and an old Suits of armor, Italian statuettes, Czech ironworks, Pers fetishes and a thousand other oddities from a hundred era crowd the shelving and floor space. The room has the look of ownership, as if civilization ha taken the time to keep a scrapbook.
My God.
The sight is overwhelming.
I had this room built some time ago.
Brenna picks up a Carolingian tapestry and runs her hand its intricate weaving.
Who are you?
That would be difficult to explain.
I'd like you to try.
Taupin picks up a Byzantine icon, brushing the dust from shoulders.
I was born Conor MacLeod in the village of Ardvrek on the High- land plain of Strathnaver in the clan of MacLeod under the King of Scotland.  On the eleventh of December, 1408.
He replaces the icon.
I have served in the armies of twelve nations, married nine women, fathered thirty-eight children and buried them all.
Taupin walks along the cases.

I carried that rifle in World War I.  This book is a 16th Century policy report for the King of Austria.  The diploma is my con- ference of degree in Latin from Trinity College.  Class of 1672. (beat) It goes on.
That's why Smith called you MacLeod.
Yes.
He knows about you.
He is older than I.
What could possibly be worth all this murder and distruction.

Sometimes I think it's just for something to do.  A conquest to be the last.  Something to hold onto while everything else around you withers and blows away.  Some- thing to replace the love that can never work.
That's insane.
Perhaps.  There is something more. An inheritance.
Of bodies.
I didn't kill the watchman.
You killed those other two.
Not the same.
What about that family in '31?
Sometimes innocents become involved.
You and your buddy make a real team, don't you?  Exchanging eloquent threats in iambic pen- tameter while hacking up all the innocents in between.
There are differences.
You kill with your left hand?
I haven't killed _you_.
Is that a threat?
Taupin moves very close.
No.
Brenna's face softens.  She turns away.
Don't.
Come here, Brenna.
Damn you.
He kisses her.
RELATIVES in period dress watch as a family member is low into the ground. A very OLD WOMAN stands stoically, supported on both side her middle aged SONS.
May God commend into his kingdom the soul of our dear departed Jason, son of Katherine-
The old woman.
And brother to Howard and James-
The two middle aged sons.
Watches the funeral quietly at a distance.

As the minister continues allows her gaze to wander.  She Conor standing at the treeline.  Her eyes crinkle in disb Releasing herself from her sons, she hobbles toward Conor Confused, the brothers watch their mother leave the cerem
Watches the woman approach but decides against moving. She stops a few paces away and looks over him.
You.
Katherine.
What are you doing here?
I owe him this.
He never knew you.
The two sons come up behind.  The three stand there: an o woman who could be 60 years Conor's senior and her two so old enough to be his father.
Is something wrong, Mother?
Howard.  James.  This is your father...
Taupin and Brenna lie together. Running her hands along the contours of his body she sees countless faint scars of bullet and sword wounds. Taupin strokes her softly.
"Brenna".  In Celtic is means "woman with raven hair".  Only chieftan's daughters were allowed it.
Brenna is lost in Taupin's scars.
What is it like?  Being you?
Empty.  And fear.  Fear of those that would kill you and fear of those that would love you.  It can never last, and in the end you always end up destroying both.
But you're known so much. History I'll only read about.
It's all the same.  Half lives that never go away.
What is it you want?
All of it finished.
Taupin and Brenna stand beside her car.  She has an armlo of documents.
Gettysburg's an hour's drive at most.  You should be back by nightfall.
Will I see you again?
Be careful.  Don't stay any longer than you have to.
Pause.  Brenna considers touching him but instead climbs into the car.
Good luck.
Detective Moran and his Inspector walk among parked squad
Are you sure?

Won't know till the records department comes back with it this after- noon.  Looks good though. They found the receipt in his townhouse.  It was pretty smeared but had Taupin's father listed as a signatory.
Round up who you can and put them on standby.
Think we should call the local P.D. out there first?
No.  I want this to be all ours.
Brenna is standing at a counter signing the last of a sta
O.K. Mrs. Taupin, that's all I need.
The clerk fills out a small sheet and hands it to her.
Just take this down the hall to the regis- trar.  Hurry up though, it's near closing time. Most everyone's gone home already.
A pair of Levis follow Brenna at a distance down the corr
Sealed from the corridor by a pair of doors, two CLERKS sit in an office mostly cleared of employees. Brenna hands the slip to a clerk.
I'll be right back.
She disappears into the rear area.
(to other clerk) Do you have a drinking fountain?
Around the corner.
Brenna steps around and takes a drink.  She looks into he reflection on the stainless steel and spends a moment fid with her hair.

Still hasn't returned.  Brenna drums her fingers on the counter top and looks around the office. The second clerk is also gone. Brenna sees something unfamiliar on the second clerk's de She steps over to it. It is a large blood stain. Brenna shoots a glance to the double doors. They're closed. Brenna rushes to the doors.  Someone's locked them. She struggles with the handles, then turns to see the Kni walking to her with his stained sword. With a SCREAM she kicks a rolling office chair into him a runs down an opposite corridor.
Flings the chair aside and knocks open the door with a SL of his palm.
